awd_titl_txt: Dissociative Bio-orthogonal Reactions of Isonitriles and Tetrazines
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program supports the group of Dr. Raphael M. Franzini from the University of Utah in a collaboration with Dr. Randall Peterson from the University of Utah to develop new chemistries to study and manipulate biomolecules in cells. Countless biological components are precisely orchestrated during cellular processes. One such process is the interaction of proteins with each other during cell signaling events. Studying these processes and events with high precision often requires activation of specific biological components at specific times during a measurement. One way to achieve this goal is to use chemical reactions. However, in order to be practical under typical biological conditions, such a chemical reaction needs to be completed in a few minutes. To obtain such short reaction times, the size of molecules involved in the reaction should be as small as possible to minimize their interference with the large biomolecules in the system. This award funds the development of new chemistries that meet these requirements and provides formal research training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students toward becoming leaders in chemistry and biology. An integral part of the research program is the establishment of the Summer Experience Advancing Research in Chemical Biology (SEARCH) program that provides research and mentoring opportunities to encourage high school students to enter a career in a science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) field. 

The research project explores the bioorthogonal chemistry of isocyanides to enable the rapid uncaging of molecules of interest in cells. The isocyano group is unique because although consisting of only two atoms it readily undergoes bioorthogonal reactions. The project advances isocyano-based groups that can be removed by exposure to tetrazines, which are another type of bioorthogonal moiety. Particular goals are to make the release reaction faster, the masking groups smaller, and to reduce the tetrazine concentration needed for the reaction to occur. The chemistry is used to study the activity of proprotein convertases during the early embryogenesis of zebrafish with spatial and temporal resolution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Chemical reactions typically occur in lab settings, but scientists are exploring ways to conduct them inside living organisms, such as cells, tissues, or eventually, humans. These reactions, compatible with living systems, offer new avenues for understanding biological processes and developing novel medicines and imaging tools. However, performing reactions inside living organisms presents challenges, requiring them to occur at room temperature, in water, and without disrupting cellular components. Currently, only a few of these specialized reactions, known as bioorthogonal reactions, are known, limiting their application in biological research and drug development.

The research supported by this grant aimed to expand our understanding of bioorthogonal reactions, with a focus on a group of molecules called isocyanides. Isocyanides possess unique properties that make them promising candidates for such reactions, yet their potential in bioorthogonal chemistry remains underexplored. Isocyanides are stable within living organisms, easily synthesized, and exhibit distinct reactivity with other molecules. Previous work in our lab investigated the reaction of isocyanides with tetrazines, linking this reaction to the controlled release of molecules for imaging or targeted drug delivery.

Building on this foundation, our project introduced a novel approach to utilize isocyanides in parallel with other bioorthogonal reactions involving tetrazines. This strategy enables the synthesis of more complex molecules and controlled release mechanisms. Additionally, we enhanced the speed of reactions between tetrazines and isocyanides, crucial for their application in living systems. Moreover, we developed new chemistry to release molecules previously inaccessible for controlled release, expanding the repertoire of drugs and molecules that can be delivered within the body.

An integral component of this project was the involvement of students in research through the SEARCH summer program. Eighteen high school students from West High School in Salt Lake City gained hands-on experience in chemistry and biology labs at the University of Utah. By exposing students, particularly those underrepresented in STEM fields, to real-life research, the program contributes to the development of a diverse group of future scientists in the USA.


Last Modified: 04/29/2024
Modified by: Raphael M Franzini
